events.title: Soul with 8 Karmas
events.description: The soul is bound by 8 types of karma.

events.title: Destroys 4 Ghāti Karmas
events.description: The soul sheds the four destructive karmas.

events.title: Attains 4 Infinite Qualities
events.description: Infinite Knowledge, Perception, Conduct, and Energy.

events.title: Becomes an Arihant
events.description: The soul attains the state of Arihant.

items.content:
Karmas are divided into two main types.

Ghāti Karmas (Destructive)

These 4 karmas directly obscure the soul's true nature.

  • Jnänävaraniya (Knowledge-obscuring)
  • Darshanävaraniya (Perception-obscuring)
  • Mohaniya (Deluding)
  • Antaräya (Obstructing)

Aghāti Karmas (Non-destructive)

These 4 karmas relate to the physical body.

  • Vedaniya (Feeling-pertaining)
  • Näm (Body-determining)
  • Gotra (Status-determining)
  • Āyushya (Lifespan-determining)

Sāmānya (Ordinary) Kevali: After enlightenment, they spend their lives in meditation until Nirvāna.

Tirthankar Kevali: They have a special'Tirthankar Nām-karma'. After enlightenment, they re-establish the Jain Sangh (four-fold order) and preach the path to liberation.

A divine, three-layered assembly hall created for a Tirthankar's sermon. It accommodates all beings without any animosity.

  • Uppermost Layer (Jewels): For heavenly beings and human beings.
  • Middle Layer (Gold): For animals.
  • Lowest Layer (Silver): Parking for vehicles.
Tirthankars have 34 extraordinary attributes. Examples include Simhāsan (divine seat), Bhāmandal (halo), Chhatra (umbrella), Ashok-vruksh (tree), Divya Dhvani (divine music), etc.

data.tagHTML: Siddhas are pure, liberated souls who have ended the cycle of birth and death forever. They reside in Siddha-kshetra, in a state of eternal bliss.

events.title: Arihant
events.description: Still bound by 4 Aghāti Karmas (Body, Lifespan, Status, Feeling).

events.title: Sheds remaining 4 Aghāti Karmas
events.description: At the end of their lifespan, these physical karmas are shed.

events.title: Becomes a Siddha
events.description: The soul is now completely free and reaches Siddha-kshetra.

data.title: The 8 Attributes of a Siddha
data.description: Qualities of a purely liberated soul.

data.tagHTML: Āchāryas are the heads of the Jain congregation (Sangh). They guide the entire community on the path of liberation and possess 36 special attributes.

items.content:
• 5 Controls over senses
  • 9 Guards of celibacy
  • 4 Controls over passions
  • 5 Great Vows (Mahävrat)
  • 5 Codes of Conduct (Ächär)
  • 5 Kinds of Carefulness (Samiti)
  • 3 Restraints (Gupti)

• 12 Austerities (6 external, 6 internal)
  • 10 Supreme Virtues (Dharma)
  • 5 Codes of Conduct (Ächär)
  • 6 Essential Duties (Ävashyak)
  • 3 Restraints (Gupti)

data.tagHTML: Upādhyāys are learned ascetics who have mastered the Jain scriptures (Āgams). Their role is to teach these scriptures. They possess 25 attributes.
Sādhus and Sādhvis have renounced worldly life to pursue spiritual upliftment. They strictly follow five great vows and have 27 core attributes.

items.content:
• 5 Great Vows
  • 6 Protections of living beings
  • 5 Controls over senses
  • 1 Carefulness (Samiti)
  • 3 Restraints (Gupti)
  • 7 Other qualities like Forgiveness, Purity, etc.

*Note: The breakdown of the 27 attributes can vary slightly between scriptures and traditions.
